content.title: Effort Thrombosis (Paget-Schroetter Syndrome)
content.definition: Primary thrombosis of the axillary-subclavian vein associated with strenuous upper extremity activity, occurring in the setting of thoracic outlet compression.

clinical_features.compression: Subclavian vein compressed between clavicle and first rib
clinical_features.repetitive_trauma: Repeated arm movements cause endothelial injury
clinical_features.stasis: Positional compression leads to stasis during activity
clinical_features.thrombosis: Virchow's triad elements lead to thrombosis

concepts.definition: Signs and symptoms of effort thrombosis.

clinical_features.symptoms: Arm swelling, heaviness, cyanosis, venous distension
clinical_features.collaterals: Prominent chest wall and shoulder collateral veins

clinical_features.duplex: Initial test - shows axillary-subclavian vein thrombus
clinical_features.venography: For thrombolysis planning, shows extent of thrombus
clinical_features.provocative_imaging: Arm abduction views to demonstrate compression

concepts.definition: Standard treatment approach for effort thrombosis.

clinical_features.venoplasty: Balloon angioplasty of residual stenosis post-decompression
clinical_features.timing: Early first rib resection associated with better outcomes

clinical_features.outcomes: 85-95% return to full activity with multimodal treatment
clinical_features.complications: Post-thrombotic syndrome if not treated aggressively

sources.reference: Illig KA et al. J Vasc Surg. 2016;64:e77-e115
Illig KA et al. Ann Vasc Surg. 2014;28:1459-1467
